titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Views of Sir Dr. Hennebel on the Jansenist controversy, 1653
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

repository.label: Repository

did.unittitle: Views of Sir Dr. Hennebel on the Jansenist controversy
did.abstract: Latin manuscript gives the views of Sir. Dr. Hennebel on the idea of grace during the Jansenist controversy. The general subject of the manuscript is grace in the theological sense, and what God's grace does, as against what man's works might do, grace as a ground of salvation, and grace achieved by following God's command. The writer is evidently against the grounds for which the "five propositions" of the Janesists were condemned by Pope Innocent X in 1653.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Views of Sir Dr. Hennebel on the Jansenist controversy, 1653, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, January 2018.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Latin manuscript gives the views of Sir. Dr. Hennebel on the idea of grace during the Jansenist controversy. The general subject of the manuscript is grace in the theological sense, and what God's grace does, as against what man's works might do, grace as a ground of salvation, and grace achieved by following God's command. The writer is evidently against the grounds for which the "five propositions" of the Janesists were condemned by Pope Innocent X in 1653.
